title: Quiz 4: Legal Issues & Record Keeping
topicName: Essential Knowledge and Skills for Healthcare Assistants
description: Test your knowledge on patient confidentiality, valid consent, and accurate record-keeping standards.

questions.question: Which Act of Parliament provides the legal framework for assessing if a person is mentally capable of making decisions?

options.text: Data Protection Act
Mental Capacity Act (2005)
Human Rights Act
Freedom of Information Act

questions.explanation: The Mental Capacity Act (2005) outlines the assessment required to determine if a person is mentally capable of decision-making.

questions.question: Informed consent requires the patient to have the ___BLANK___ to understand the information and decide.
questions.explanation: Capacity is the ability to use and understand information to make a decision.
questions.hint: The legal term for ability to make decisions.

questions.question: In England and Wales, children under 16 can NEVER give consent for their own treatment.
questions.explanation: Usually parents consent, BUT 'Gillick Competency' allows children under 16 to consent if they have sufficient understanding and intelligence.
questions.hint: Have you heard of Gillick Competency?

questions.question: Which of the following are key principles of the Caldicott Report regarding patient information? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Justify the purpose for collecting information
Access should be on a 'need-to-know' basis
Share information with anyone who asks
Do not use patient-identifiable information unless necessary

questions.explanation: Caldicott principles emphasize minimizing use of identifiable info, justifying purpose, and restricting access to need-to-know.
questions.hint: Think about privacy and minimizing data exposure.

questions.question: Match the record-keeping principle with its explanation:

pairs.right: Record as soon as possible, at least within 24 hours
Fact-based, without speculation or offensive subjective comments
Clear handwriting that can be read by others
Signed/dated or traceable via digital login

questions.explanation: Records must be timely, factual (objective), readable, and traceable to the author.

questions.question: What is the term used when information is given to others, which requires consent unless it is in the public interest?
questions.explanation: Disclosure means the giving of information.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'If it isn't documented, then in the eyes of the law it never happened' refer to?

options.text: The importance of verbal handover
The legal necessity of record-keeping as evidence of care
A myth that is not true
The need for video recording

questions.explanation: Courts rely on written records. Without documentation, there is no proof that care was delivered.

questions.question: When can you break confidentiality without patient consent?

options.text: When a relative asks
If you think it's interesting gossip
If there is a risk of significant harm or it is in the public interest (e.g. serious crime)
Never, under any circumstances

questions.explanation: Disclosure is justified in the public interest, such as preventing serious harm, child abuse, or serious crime.

questions.question: You should never delete or amend records without a full and signed explanation of why this was done.
questions.explanation: Records are legal documents. Alterations must be transparent and justified to maintain integrity.
questions.hint: Can you just use Tipp-Ex or delete a line without saying why?

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of accidental breaches of confidentiality? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Leaving computer screens visible to the public
Discussing a patient in the supermarket
Discussing a patient in a private clinical meeting
Posting about work on social media

questions.explanation: Screens, public gossip, and social media are breaches. Clinical meetings are appropriate professional sharing.
questions.hint: Where can the public overhear or see?
